definition: When you enter a country, follow the local customs (idiom); do as the natives do/When in Rome, do as the Romans do
to enter/to go into/to join/to become a member of/to confirm or agree with/abbr. for 入聲|入声[ru4 sheng1]
to follow/to comply with/varying according to.../to allow/subsequently

sentences.english: But when you go to the United States, you had better "do as the Romans do."
sentences.chinese: 若你们去美国，最好还是“入境随俗”。

definition: to make a fool of oneself
One who does not know is not guilty/If one does not know any better, one cannot be held responsible
(Tw) excuse me/to be sorry/(Taiwanese, Tai-lo pr. [pháinn-sè]
nobody will find fault with extra courtesy (idiom)/courtesy costs nothing
etiquette/(old) gradation of etiquette with social status

Since they have come, we should make them comfortable (idiom). Since we're here, take it easy./Since this is so, we should accept it./Now we have come, let's stay and take the rough with the smooth./If you can't do anything to prevent it, you might as well sit back and enjoy it.
pinyin: ji4 lai2 zhi1 , ze2 an1 zhi1
si4 hai3 zhi1 nei4 jie1 xiong1 di4

definition: to gesticulate/to make lively gestures (while talking)/also written 比手劃腳|比手划脚
Only an outstanding talent can recognize current trends (idiom). A wise man submits to circumstances.
pinyin: shi2 shi2 wu4 zhe3 wei4 jun4 jie2
